turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We'll hear argument now in Number 86-6284, John T. Satterwhite v. Texas.
Mr. Woods, you may proceed whenever you're ready.

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:

This is a criminal case from the State of Texas, involving a death penalty which was imposed on the Petitioner, and a case that was tried in 1979, error complained of and the question presented before the Court is whether there was a denial of effective assistance to counsel in the allowing of testimony of Dr. James P. Grigson, a Dallas psychiatrist, during the punishment phase of the Defendant's trial.

The complained-of error is couched on this Court's decision in Estelle v. Smith in that counsel was not advised nor notified previously to the order appointing Dr. Grigson to examine the Defendant for two reasons.
One was for the purpose of determining competency to stand trial and the other was the purpose of determining future dangerousness.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: Was that by court order?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: Yes, sir, it was.
This order was signed and filed by the District Attorney's Office, the prosecutor in San Antonio, Texas, on April 18th, 1979.
Trial counsel was appointed April 10th, 1979.
The order was submitted to the Court in whose case, the Petitioner's case, was indicted.
So, counsel should have been advised prior to at least the examination of the Defendant.
The Defendant was not examined by Dr. Grigson till May 3rd of 1979.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: This is the same Dr. Grigson that appears in every Texas case or did appear?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: Is he now deceased?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: No.
I believe he's still practicing.
I don't believe he is testifying anymore in these types of cases, at least I have not heard.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: Mr. Woods, what's the role of defense counsel in connection with one of these examinations by a psychiatrist in Texas?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: Justice, the role as far as the defense counsel would be is to determine or to at least advise the client of the scope of the examination.
Let him know what the impact of it could be, what ramifications could be derived from it.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: The attorney doesn't actually sit in and participate at the time of the examination.

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: Such a request, of course, was not made and I don't think the attorney would necessarily--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: But it doesn't normally occur, is that right?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: --No, I don't think so.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: It would simply be a matter of consultation of some kind with the defendant in advance of the examination?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: To let him know what the ramifications could possibly be as to the examination.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: Now, there were two other doctors appointed in this instance to examine Mr. Satterwhite, is that right?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: Yes.
That was Dr. Holbrook, I believe.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: And in each case, did his attorney advise... were you representing him below?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: Yes, I was.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: Did you talk to him in advance of those... each of those examinations?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: I was not advised.
First of all, Dr. Holbrook did not examine Mr. Satterwhite.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: There was a psychologist who did.

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: Dr. Betty Lou Schroeder.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: Yes, and did you talk to Mr. Satterwhite before that examination?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: Dr. Schroeder examined Mr. Satterwhite on March 16th, before I was appointed to represent him.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: And not again?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: The testimony that was elicited in the trial shows that she talked to him on several occasions.
Now, specifically when is unknown to anybody.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: That testimony is not challenged.

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: Well, basically, it is challenged, but, of course, it's challenged through the means of the complaint of Dr. Grigson, because of Dr. Grigson's impact on the jury, which, of course, is buttressed by the state's argument.

They argued and supported their position for the death penalty and for the affirmative findings of Special Issue Number 2, stating that Dr. Grigson's a Dallas psychiatrist and a medical doctor and not referring to just a mere county-employed psychologist.
And, so, the impact to the jury was very great.
Of course, the impact of Dr. Grigson to any jury is devastating and it's for those reasons for which, of course,--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: Now, what was the April 18th order signed by the Court?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: --That was the... there was an order signed.
That was the order for appointment of a Dr. Holbrook and Dr. Schroeder to examine the Defendant for purposes of mental competency.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: And you knew about that order?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: No, ma'am.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: Never?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: Did not... was not told.
I was not advised.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: Never looked at the file?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: I saw the file several times.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: You did not see that order in the file?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: Well, I can only tell you from my own personal observation and knowledge, I didn't see that order in the file--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: But it was there?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: --Well, I tell you, I saw the file on, I can say, two occasions, both of which I did not see the order in the file nor did I see Dr. Grigson's letter that he wrote on May 3rd.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: I'm talking about the April 18th order.

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: The April 18th order did not surface until after, I'd say it was, about the middle of May, and that's when I prepared several motions which were filed May 29th.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Isn't there a copy of that for each case?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: The entry of a docket sheet as to that particular order, if made, and I don't have it in front of me right now, was not necessarily entered, as I could see.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Well, has it ever been entered?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: I don't remember.
I couldn't tell you.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: I suppose if it's on the docket, entered on the docket sheet and there's a date on it, that's what you usually look at to see what's in a file.

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Did you look at it?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: I looked.
I did look at the docket sheet because sometimes they keep--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Well, don't you think you ought to look at the docket sheet?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: --Well, that's true, but, Your Honor, the point is that in examining the file... first of all, the order that was presented in front of the Judge, after I was appointed as counsel, was not even... in fact, I was not even provided any notice for it.
Without notice--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: Wouldn't Texas practice ordinarily provide that if there's an attorney of record for the Defendant, that a copy of that... at least a proposed formal order would be served?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: --As far as I'm concerned, yes.
In every court I've practiced in, there's always been a notice or certificate of service to opposing counsel.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: What date were you appointed?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: April 10th, I believe, yes.
I was--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Was April 18th the order serviced?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: --That's the date the order was signed by the Judge.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: And you didn't see it until May some time?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: I didn't see it until mid-May.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: Is this the Schroeder order or the Grigson order?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: This is actually the Holbrook order.
There was never an order for Dr. Grigson.
He came in under the guise of the Holbrook order.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: I thought that the order pursuant to which Schroeder examined your client was entered before you were appointed.

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: Yes, sir.
That order was entered the day after he was arrested.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: What order is it we're talking about?
What were the contents of the order entered on April 18th?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: The contents of the order on April 18th dealt with the appointment of Drs.
Holbrook and Schroeder to examine John Satterwhite for purposes of determining competency to stand trial and to determine whether or not he would be a continuing threat to society in the future.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: You're not directly challenging either the Holbrook or the other expert testimony, are you?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: There was no expert testimony from Holbrook.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, then, the other, the Schroeder.

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: I am effectively challenging--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: You're not saying that it was a violation of the Sixth Amendment to have permitted her to testify?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: --Her testimony came in based upon her examination at a time prior to counsel being appointed and then, as she testified, at a time after counsel was appointed.
She said and the record should reflect that she was aware of counsel being appointed but did not notify counsel of her examinations.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: But, now, was that point raised in the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: The point was raised more towards Dr. Grigson than it was--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: Much more, almost to the exclusion of--

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: --I'll have to agree.
That's true.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: --So, but, now, do you challenge the Schroeder testimony here, not having challenged it in the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: Well, it was challenged in the Motion for Rehearing in the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: And what did the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals do with the Motion for Rehearing?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: They did not write an opinion.
They denied the Motion for Rehearing.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: Now, when was the order appointing Dr. Grigson entered by the Court, do you know?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: There was no order for Dr. Grigson ever submitted.
The only thing that was--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: Well, the Court did something or he wouldn't have made examination presumably.

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: --The Court... Dr. Grigson acted in the stead of Dr. Holbrook.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: Relying on the appointment of Dr. Holbrook.

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: Yes, ma'am.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: Did they practice together?
Is that--

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: I don't recall where exactly Dr. Holbrook is from.
He is from the North Texas area, I believe.
He may also be from Dallas.
I'm not sure.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: --At the beginning of the argument, I asked you whether Dr. Grigson's examination was pursuant to court order, and I thought you said yes.

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: Well, of course, technically, he was not in the body of the order.
He testified that he examined the Defendant as per a court order, which was arranged through the District Attorney's Office.
That is the basis of what his testimony was.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Do you accept that, that he was examining him pursuant to some order?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: I can only accept that because he wrote a letter to the trial judge on May 8th, about five days after he examined the Defendant.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: Is there any court order which specifically names Dr. Grigson?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: There is not.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Did the same judge that appointed you sign the order of April 18th?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: And didn't send you a copy after he appointed you?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: No copy.

It's not so much the substance of the testimony, of the psychiatric testimony or the psychological testimony, it's the lack of notice to counsel, the opportunity to at least advise the client of what the ramifications of the examination could be.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: Well, Mr. Woods, let me ask you this.
You say no harmless error standard can be applied.
What if the state had not put Dr. Grigson on the stand but, in fact, had had Dr. Grigson examine the Defendant and simply didn't use the testimony?
Would you be making the same argument, that that's error and it's error per se?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: If Dr. Grigson did not testify, I may not be here today.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: Why not?
You're saying that it's the appointment without notice to you that creates the problem.

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: If Dr. Grigson had, as was in Barefoot v. Texas, if Dr. Grigson had, in fact,... notice been provided to counsel and he did examine him--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: No, no, no notice provided to you.
Just like you say happened here, and Dr. Grigson examined the Defendant but the state doesn't try to use the testimony.

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: --Well, if the state didn't use the testimony, of course, there's no harm to the Defendant.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: So, we do apply harmless error then in the question?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: Well, I believe you'd almost have to, yes.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: Then, why shouldn't we apply harmless error here?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: Well, I have seen some decisions which this Court has... there seems to be a trend towards harmless error doctrine or Chapman towards these cases in which--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: So, you don't object to that really?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: --Well, because of the trends of the Court and the law of this land, I would say no.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: And it would be your submission then that in this case, error was not harmless?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: Exactly.
And as far as the harm to be effected, we have to, of course, look at what a jury is going to do.
Is a jury... and do we have any type of a standard in which we can say what a jury is going to say.

I think as this Court said in Cal v. Romulus, California v. Romulus, that there's no objective or normative marker available to say what a jury is really thinking, and if, in fact, there is a harm or at least there is the error and if the error is of constitutional dimensions, such as in Estelle v. Smith, without the notice, then this Defendant has been harmed because the jury very well could have used that testimony, even though there may have been some very horrible fact situations underlying the prosecution.
We don't know, and for that reason, we cannot really peer into the minds of the jury and see exactly what they would do, and it's on that basis that I believe that harm has been made.

It is the conduct so much not of a state agency as it is of the prosecutor of an attorney, one in which knows by the ethical rules should be noticing opposing counsel of motions that are presented to the court.
This is exactly what is being complained of.
More so than anything else.

The harm... if this is harmless error, it is still the Government's burden of proving this beyond a reasonable doubt, and they have got to prove that the error did not contribute to the verdict of taint.

Now, I don't see how that could possibly in this case, especially since this Court has before reviewed the testimony of Dr. Grigson, and there's no question about it but for the notice provision, but for the availability of a defendant to have his counsel, at least to talk to him prior to such examination, he may not have said anything and there may not have been an examination, there may not have been even testimony, and this is one thing that is just so ever-presently clear.

There is continued repeated references made to the Dallas psychiatrist and that he was a medical doctor in the jury argument, and it's this basis in which the state's use of this improperly-admitted evidence that the Defendant was denied a fair trial, was denied effective assistance of counsel, and it's on that basis, following Chapman, upon the harmless error doctrine, that harm was made.
Harm was committed.
I reserve my time.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Woods.
Mr. Palmer, we'll hear now from you.

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
In disputing the harmless error finding of the Court below, the briefs filed by Satterwhite and by the amicus advance essentially two arguments.
The first being that this type of error can never be harmless, and as I understand Mr. Woods, he's abandoned that argument here today.
The second argument then, and the issue for the Court to decide, is whether on the facts of this case, the state proved that Dr. Grigson's testimony was harmless beyond a reasonable doubt.
Now, we have made an argument that there was no Sixth Amendment violation in connection with Dr. Grigson's examination of Satterwhite.
Assuming for the sake of argument that we are wrong on that point, given the trial record before this Court, any error in the admission of Dr. Grigson's testimony certainly was harmless.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: You don't suggest that your opposition has abandoned the notion that it was harmful?

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: One of the arguments made at some length in the amicus brief was that this particular type of error can never be harmless, and I understand that argument to be abandoned.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Do you think we're bound by that abandonment?
You don't think we're free to decide this kind of error could never be harmless?
Having Dr. Grigson, who is a Professional witness in these cases.
He's a specialist in testifying on capital punishment cases, isn't he, or he was?

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: He was, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: And doesn't the state him because he's particularly persuasive to juries?
Doesn't he have a record of seventy-nine out of eighty or something like that?

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: I don't know what Dr. Grigson's record is.
I assume the state him just as they use any other witness, expert or otherwise, because they believe he is persuasive.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: Because they believe he'll be persuasive to the jury.

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: And do we have any reason to doubt that he was persuasive to the jury in this case?

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: No reason to doubt it.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: Then, how could we say it was harmless?
How could we possibly say it was harmless?

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: Well, for a number of reasons.
First of all, Dr. Grigson's testimony was not as critical to the state's case on punishment as Satterwhite would have the Court believe.
It is true that his testimony was important in that it went to an ultimate issue on punishment, one of the two special issues submitted to the punishment phase of the Texas capital trial.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: Wasn't he the only doctor who testified on that issue?

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: He was the only medical doctor.
There was testimony from a psychologist, Dr. Schroeder, whose testimony was very similar to that of Dr. Grigson.
Her diagnosis of Satterwhite was virtually the same as that of Dr. Grigson, and there was no evidence by Satterwhite to the contrary, psychiatric or otherwise.
There was no evidence whatsoever presented by Satterwhite in either the guilt or the punishment phases.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: You feel that his testimony on a scale of one to ten, he's a ten plus?

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: Your Honor, I--

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: It would not be harmful in any way?

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: --I would not agree with that.
I've never met the man or heard him testify.
I don't have a personal opinion, but it's the state's position in this case that a particular witness' testimony cannot be deemed to be never harmless simply because he is a persuasive witness.

Under traditional harmless error analysis, the Court looks at the entire record of the case and considers the number of factors, including whether the state's case is overwhelming, whether the evidence is cumulative, whether it was important.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: Is Dr. Grigson alive?

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: As far as I know, Your Honor.
Dr. Holbrook, who--

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Blackmun
turn.text: As far as you know, he is alive right now?
Is the state still using him in every single criminal case?

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: --Again, Your Honor, I don't know.
The prosecution of this case is in the trial court.
Whoever handled it at the local District Attorney's Office.
There is no coordination.
Their office is in the Attorney General's Office.
So I simply unaware.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: Mr. Palmer, what... where do we find the court order appointing Dr. Grigson?

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: There is no court order appointing Dr. Grigson.
There was an order entered on April 18th appointing Dr. Holbrook and I think, as Mr. Woods has stated, it was Dr. Grigson performing the examination instead of Dr. Holbrook.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: Were they practicing psychiatry together?

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: Your Honor, I do not know, and I don't want to represent that as a fact to the Court, but I'm under the impression that they were.
They were both used extensively in capital trials at this time in Texas.
Dr.--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: Is there any evidence of record that defense counsel was sent a copy or otherwise served with a copy of that April 18th order?

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: --No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: Do you think that is a requirement?
Notice to counsel of proposed examination?

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: Certainly, Your Honor, and we have argued that counsel is effectively put on notice by the fact that the court order was filed in the record of the case, was filed the same day it was entered, April 18th, some two weeks prior to the examination.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: But is that ordinary practice in Texas, that you expect a lawyer for a party to the case to be bound by an order of which he had never seen a copy, that was simply put in the case file?

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: Again, Your Honor, I'm not aware of what's ordinary practice statewide.
Apparently, in 1979, in Bexar County, this was a common practice.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Was the Defendant required to submit for the examination?

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: No, he was not.
If I may back up a moment,--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Well, but he did and I suppose that counsel might have advised him not to submit.

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: --He might have.

Our argument that counsel was put on notice is really twofold; one being the fact that the order was on file for two weeks prior to the examination, and the second part being that prior to counsel being appointed, Satterwhite had been examined by Dr. Schroeder, at which time he waived his Sixth Amendment right.
Between the time of Dr. Schroeder's examination and that of Dr. Grigson, counsel was appointed.
It strains credulity to assert that Satterwhite and counsel did not discuss the previous examination and any possible future examinations in light of that.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: How could he have discussed the possible future examinations when they hadn't even been requested?

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: At the time counsel was appointed, there had been one examination requested and performed.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: Yes, but I know, but you're saying that the client should have told the lawyer that another examination which hadn't even been requested might take place.

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: I'm saying, Your Honor, that competent counsel would tell his client, hey, don't let them do this to you again.
If this happens again, don't submit.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Well, more likely, if the counsel is told, he would say, well, I guess that phase of it is over, they aren't going to do it again.

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: That's possible, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Wouldn't you sort of think that?
One is enough.
Usually it is.

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: Perhaps so.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Yeah.
Mr. Woods, I think, told us that... I think you've just said that that order of April 18th was in the file at least two weeks?

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: It was in the file as of April 18th.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Well, now, where do you get that?
I thought Mr. Woods had told us he looked at the file twice and there was no order then.

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: The order is in the transcript before the Court.
It was file marked April 18th.
Stamped with the Clerk's stamp, showing it as filed on that date.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Is there a docket sheet?
Is it listed on the docket sheet?

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: No.
The only docket sheet in the transcript, Your Honor, is the trial docket sheet of the proceedings in open court.
But the order in question very definitely bears the Clerk's stamp, showing when it was filed.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Do you disbelieve the representation to us that when he looked at it, it wasn't there?

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: I have no reason to disbelieve Mr. Woods on any point.
I'm simply telling the Court what the record reveals.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: Where is it now?

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: It's in the transcript which is in the Court's possession, along with the entire trial records.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: All it says is it was filed and you don't know where it was filed, do you?

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: The file is maintained--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: It must have been filed in the Judge's file.

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: --No, Your Honor.
This is the file of the District Clerk.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Marshall
turn.text: Does it have a court trial on it?
I mean, a stamp that says the Court?

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: It has a stamp saying it's filed by the District Clerk's Office, yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: Was there a finding by the Texas Court that it was on file?

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: I don't--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: I mean, what I'm saying, if Mr. Woods is wrong about, you know, if he says it wasn't there, maybe that should have been raised before the Texas Court?
Is there a finding by the Texas Court?

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: --There was not a specific finding one way or the other.
I think implicit in the decision of the Texas Court is that assuming it was on file, it was inadequate notice.
I believe that's the legal conclusion.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: Why is that implicit in the decision?

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: Because, as a matter of record, the thing was filed and was stamped filed.
It's entitled to presumption of regularity and the defense has never questioned that it was filed on that date.

Mr. Woods represented he didn't see it when he saw the file, but there's no reason to doubt it was filed on the date it shows to have been filed, and if it was filed on that date, then I can only surmise that that is implicit in the Court's holding that it was not sufficient.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Part of your submission was that the lack of notice was irrelevant as long as the order is on file.
The attorney is charged with everything... with notice of everything in the file, is that it?

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: That is our first argument.
Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: Has this Court ever held that?

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: Has the Texas Court ever held that?

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: I'm not aware that they have.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: So much would depend on local practice, it seems to me, and there's really no representation or anything very authoritative here about what the practice in Texas is.

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: That is true, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: What city was this in?

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: San Antonio.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: San Antonio.
That's a pretty big city, isn't it?

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: I mean, you usually don't run over to the Clerk's office every day to see what's been filed in the cases that you are involved in.

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: Well, assuming for the sake of argument that this examination was conducted in violation of Satterwhite's right to counsel, we would submit that certainly in this record any error was harmless.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Do you know whether or not we possibly got a copy of that order of April 18th?

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: The record is silent on that.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: Well, we do know that Dr. Grigson must have because on May 8th, he wrote a letter to the Judge reporting on the results of his examination.

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: This is true.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: Does the record tell us whether a copy of Dr. Grigson's letter to the Judge went to the Defendant or his counsel?

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: I don't know that it does, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: I couldn't find any indication of it.

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: But, again, the letter was placed in the file on that same day.
At the punishment hearing, the punishment hearing lasted five and a half hours, Dr. Grigson was one of a number of witnesses.
There were eight witnesses to Satterwhite's bad reputation.
There was testimony by the psychologist, Dr. Schroeder, whose diagnosis of Satterwhite was the same as that of Dr. Grigson.
There was testimony about Satterwhite's prior criminal record, two misdemeanor convictions, two felony convictions.
There was testimony about Satterwhite's violent nature.
A year and a half before the capital offense, he attacked his blind father-in-law in the man's home, shot him twice through the door, put him in the hospital for a month.
Some six months prior to this capital offense, he was arrested for carrying a concealed weapon which he attempted to pull from his waist band and use it on a policeman who accosted him.
In the face of all of this very damaging testimony, Satterwhite presented no evidence whatsoever, no psychiatric testimony, a reputation evidence, nothing.

It's... as I said, the punishment hearing lasted five and a half hours, and we really can't tell from the record how long Dr. Grigson was on the stand, but it was certainly not the bulk of that time or anything approaching it.

Now, as far as how the prosecutor relied on the testimony, again the record doesn't show how much time elapsed during the final argument on punishment, but it does show in the printed statement of facts of the trial that the prosecutor's argument occupied 291 lines of argument, nine of those were devoted to Dr. Grigson.
I would submit to the Court that that is not heavy reliance on Dr. Grigson's testimony.
Unless the Court is prepared to say that this type... well, perhaps I should back up a moment.
Only last term in Buchanan v. Kentucky, the Court stated that this type of error can be harmless.
In Buchanan, the defendant claimed that he was examined in violation of his right to counsel and that there was error in the admission of psychiatric testimony.
The Court rejected that, holding there was no Estelle v. Smith violation and then also stated, however, even if there had been, it would be harmless.
So, I think there's no substance whatsoever to Satterwhite's argument that this particular type of error cannot be harmless.
That being so, I would submit to the Court that certainly on this record, it was harmless beyond a reasonable doubt.

When the state puts on overwhelming evidence to support the issues on punishment and when the defendant puts on no evidence whatsoever, and when the complained-of testimony is essentially the same as that of properly-admitted testimony, it would seem that any error was harmless beyond any doubt whatsoever.
Satterwhite has chosen to focus on the fact that Dr. Grigson testified on a critical issue and from that argues that this can never be harmless.
However, the admission of a confession taken in violation of Miranda can be harmless.
Certainly, Dr. Grigson's testimony on punishment is no more damaging to the defendant than his own word inculpating himself.
If that sort of error could be harmless, we submit to the Court that this can, too, and that on this record, it certainly was.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: Mr. Palmer, this... the testimony of Dr. Grigson, though, was the... am I correct that it was the only expert testimony by a psychiatric on the matter of future dangerousness?

turn.speaker: charles_a_palmer
turn.label: Mr. Charles A. Palmer
turn.text: That is true, Your Honor.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Palmer.
Mr. Woods, you have fifteen minutes remaining.

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: I'll be short.
Your Honor, just in response, the representations I made are accurate.

It's one of these things that I don't think in a city the size of San Antonio, about the tenth largest in the nation here, that the counsel here can be charged with the responsibility of going each and every day to check the Court's jackets, and also with regard to this practice, local practice, in Texas or specifically San Antonio, usually motions are noticed to opposing counsel, and very rarely have I seen otherwise, and I believe that the Court can take the same posture.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, now, does this ordinarily require a motion?
Does the state ordinarily make a motion to the judge for an examination?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: The practice has been.
Now, I'll say since the Estelle v. Smith was handed down, Dr. Grigson has not been used in San Antonio.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: But supposing the state wants an examination of a defendant by an expert witness, is that ordinarily accomplished by a motion under Texas procedure?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: Yes, sir, it is.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: Not just an order filed by the judge?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: It's usually a practice of a motion and an order, is what I've seen.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: But, here, I gather, at least there's no record of any motion having been made and just the order filed?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: I believe there was a motion and an order both signed by... the motion was signed by the prosecutor and the order was signed.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: Was it in one document, a motion and an order?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: No.
Two separate documents.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: And you say that the defense attorney got... was served copies of neither the motion nor the order?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Well, the purpose of the examination was for what?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: To determine whether or not--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: Competence?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: --Competency and future dangerousness, and the body of that motion and order of that.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: But if there's some question of competence, I suppose the district judge or the trial judge has got some obligation of his own to respond, if there's some question in his mind about competency, wholly aside from any motion.
He could and should order an examination, shouldn't he?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: Justice, that's correct, except in this case, there was no raising of the issue of competency whatsoever by the Defendant, by his counsel being myself, or by anybody except the prosecutor.
The State of Texas, the attorneys, they're the only ones that raised it.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: Mr. Woods, is there no local rule of practice governing notice to be given to counsel in criminal cases?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: I know of no such rule which says that no notice has to be given to opposing counsel.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: Well, do you know of a rule that says notice must be given?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: I can't say that there is a specific local rule that says that, ma'am, no.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: Have you checked the local rules?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: I have read the local rules before, but I don't recall anything such as that.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice O'Connor
turn.text: Not in preparation for this case, I take it?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: Well, certainly not that.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, you know, when your opposing party makes a motion, not necessarily in a capital case, but just in the run-of-the-mind criminal case, in a run-of-the-mind civil case, doesn't he ordinarily serve opposing counsel with a copy of the motion?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: Absolutely.
In fact, more specifically in a civil case, that would be grounds for reversal of the trial if it was adversely decided against that party.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: Doesn't that practice pertain in criminal cases, too?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: Everywhere I've practiced in the criminal courts and also civil courts, that practice has always been maintained.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: Beyond that, isn't it also typical in your motion to include a proof of service or some kind of an indication that the opposing counsel received notice?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: That's correct.
In fact, in this case, the record--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: The record doesn't show that.

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: --Yes, sir.

In this case, the record reflects that all of the pre-trial motions filed by the Defendant did have a certificate of service because the joint appendix shows that the certificate of service was omitted from printing, and the prosecutor's motion and order, there is no such notation made.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Woods, you had been appointed ten days before the order of April 18th.

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: Eight days.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Eight days before.
The prosecutor knew of your appointment?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: I would assume he did.
Now, there are several... at that time, the Bexar County Attorney's Office had over fifty prosecutors.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Well, I don't quite understand this.
If he knew that you were representing and he filed a motion for the judge without sending a copy to you.

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: That's basically it.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: Maybe your appointment was just noted, put in the file, and no notice sent to him.

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: They let me go my way.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Scalia
turn.text: Yes, but the judge, it was the same judge, so the judge certainly knew it.

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: The judge that appointed me is the same judge that signed the April 18th order.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: And tried the lawsuit.
Same judge tried the case, didn't he?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: In fact, the arraignment was on April 13th, in which, of course, the prosecutor knew that--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: You were there?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: --There was a representative on April 13th.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: And then he filed a motion on the 18th and didn't send you a copy?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: What about Judge... I mean, Dr. Grigson's letter of May 8th?
Did he send you a copy of that?

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: I did not receive a copy of it.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice Stevens
turn.text: I don't think they like you very much.

turn.speaker: richard_d_woods
turn.label: Mr. Richard D. Woods
turn.text: You may be right.
Or maybe not Mr. Satterwhite.
Counsel referred to Buchanan v. Kentucky in his argument and I'd just like to point out that in that case, the defense was used of extreme emotional disturbance.
They, in fact, did join with the prosecution in the motion for the psychiatric examination.
So, therefore, it could very well be deemed proper to use psychiatric evidence in rebuttal to a defensive issue.
We don't have that in this case.
There was no such allusion to any psychiatric evidence by the Defendant because no defense was raised.
And with that, I'll close.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Woods.
The case is submitted.
